target: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo man with CAD with prior MI, ischemic cardiomyopathy, HTN, alcohol abuse, chronic pancreatitis/pancreatic insufficiency, who presented with painless jaundice. RUQ ultrasound showed pancreatic mass and LFTs were elevated in obstructive pattern, so he was admitted for ERCP and EUS. ERCP/EUS did not show stones or a mass, though did have 2cm CBD stricture with sphincterotomy. ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: # POSSIBLE PANCREATIC MASS # BILIARY OBSTRUCTION # PAINLESS JAUNDICE # CHOLELITHIASIS: RUQ ultrasound on ___ showed "hypoechoic mass in the region of the pancreatic head measures approximately 4.7 x 3.0 x 3.3 cm" and marked intra- and extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation due to obstruction at pancreatic head. These findings were concerning for malignancy, so he underwent ERCP and EUS on ___. ERCP showed no mass or stone, with 2cm CBD stricture and he had stent placement and sphincterotomy. EUS showed hypoechoic pancreas with areas of stranding, mild atrophy of tail, and pancreatic duct cut off at pancreatic head. Biopsy was taken of pancreatic head, but no distinct lesion or mass was seen. CT pancreas protocol was obtained, which also showed no discrete pancreatic mass, though showed a 1cm area within pancreatic head where pancreatic duct is not visualized, with mild prominence of upstream pancreatic duct (3mm). This corresponded with the transition point seen on EUS and isodense lesion is still a possibility. Intra and extrahepatic bile duct dilation was improved compared to RUQ ultrasound, after CBD stent placement. He had mild-moderate LUQ abdominal pain the evening after ERCP but improved and he was tolerating regular diet prior to discharge. Repeat LFTs were trending down after stent placement. His pain was managed with PRN Tylenol, oxycodone, IV morphine for pain and discharged with PRN Tylenol and oxycodone. ERCP team said that in absence of pancreatic mass, his EUS findings may be consistent with chronic pancreatitis as well as autoimmune pancreatitis. # CHRONIC PANCREATITIS: Continued home Creon TID with meals # ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSM: AAA was 4.6cm in ___ and 5.4cm on ultrasound on ___. He also has bilateral iliac artery aneurysms up to 3.1cm on right and 2.8cm on left. He was asymptomatic without concern for rupture. I had recommended outpatient follow up with vascular surgery, but anesthesia was concerned about AAA prior to ERCP/EUS and wanted vascular consult. Ultimately, there was no intervention needed prior to ERCP/EUS, but discussed with vascular and recommended CTA torso for better comparison with size in ___. CTA torso showed stable 4.6cm AAA with no dissection or flow-limiting stenosis. Vascular surgery recommended repeat CTA abd/pelvis and clinic visit in 6 months. # HYPONATREMIA (RESOLVED): Na was 132 on admission and most likely to poor oral intake prior to admission. He received IV fluids and Na was 139 on discharge. CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: # HLD: Continued home atorvastatin QPM # TOBACCO USE: He was encouraged to pursue tobacco cessation and given daily nicotine patch, though it sounds as though this was not previously covered by insurance. # ANXIETY: Continued home Bupropion BID, Lexapro (dose is > maximum 10 mg daily but pt confirms that he takes 20 at home), Prazosin, Gabapentin, PRN Trazodone QHS. # CAD/ischemic cardiomyopathy: Asymptomatic - Continue home aspirin 81mg daily, Lisinopril 5mg daily # HTN: Continue home Lisinopril but held home Metoprolol XL since HR was in ___. # PRESUMED GERD: Continued PPI especially if he is taking NSAIDS prior to admission. # History of alcohol abuse: He had no signs of withdrawal. He was continued on multivitamin and thiamine daily. # Anemia: Hb was 13.2 and decreased to 11.5 without signs of blood loss and no hypotension. Of note, all cell counts decreased and likely in setting of receiving IV fluids. Hb decreased to 10.4 on discharge without signs of bleeding. TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES: - Follow up CBD brushings and biopsy from pancreatic head, which are pending - Will need repeat ERCP in 4 weeks for stent removal and re-evaluation. ERCP office will schedule follow up appointment - Follow up pending ___ level - Vascular surgery recommended repeat CTA abd/pelvis and clinic visit in 6 months. Call to schedule appointment in ___. - Monitor CBC to make sure anemia does not progressively worsen - Determine if/when to restart Metoprolol XL, which was held due to bradycardia (asymptomatic). Mr. ___ is clinically stable for discharge today. The total time spent today on discharge planning, counseling and coordination of care was greater than 30 minutes.

target: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing Hysteropexy (using Elevate system from AMS), posterior colporrhaphy, insertion of biologic graft in the posterior compartment. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with Iv dilaudid and toradol. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her foley was removed and a formal voiding trial was performed. She passed her voiding trial with the following values: 300cc instilled, 250cc voided, 50cc straight catheterized; 300cc instilled, 250cc voided, 80cc bladder scanned. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to percocet and motrin. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy in conjunction with abdominal wall reconstruction and completion colectomy and end ileostomy. He was initially admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ however was transferred to ___ on ___. Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PCA with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake on, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint and monitored for afib with telemetry. Course was notable for multiple bouts of tachycardia (Afib RVR) associated with physical activity with HR in the 130s-150s. BP remained stable during these episodes and tachycardia self-resolved with rest. This improved with continued physical therapy and initiation of home beta blocker (IV metoprolol when NPO, then PO atenolol). Patient was restarted on home atenolol for rate control and rivaroxaban for AC. Patient also with a longstanding history of hypertension. He was continued on a clonidine patch inpatient but home amlodipine, lisinopril, and furosemide were held due to normotension. Patient will follow up with PCP prior to restarting. Pulmonary: The patient has history of asthma and was started on home asthma medications or substitutes. Patient fairly non-compliant with use of CPAP which was available. GI/GU: #Ileus: On POD patient was kept NPO and started on IVF. He was advanced to sips on POD#2 and then to clear liquids on POD#3. Foley was maintained until POD#2 and then discontinued. Patient able to void freely. On POD#4, ostomy continued without flatus or output and abdomen appeared distended. KUB revealed some dilated bowel loops and probable ileus. Foley catheter was placed in ostomy with small liquid stool and gas output. In addition, urine output was noted to be marginal so patient was given albumin for concern for intravascular dehydration. POD#5 showed good stoma function with stoma catheter in place and patient was advanced to a regular diet. On POD#6, the stoma catheter was discontinued. Patient had no ostomy output and very poor urine output on POD#7. He was also noted to have nausea and a distended abdomen. KUB revealed ileus and gastroparesis. Ostomy stoma was catheterized again and an NG tube was placed with immediate output of 3 liters of green fluid. Patient was made NPO and placed back on IV fluids. On ___ the NGT fell out but was replaced. Due to continued poor output from the ostomy, on ___/P was ordered which was consistent with post-surgical changes and no evidence of a leak. Prevena vac and JP drain (if <25cc/day) were to be removed prior to discharge. #Acute kidney injury: Creatinine steadily increased during immediate post-operative course from 1.8 post op to at peak 2.0, though continued to make adequate urine throughout. Cr normalized with continued mIVF. Prior to CT a/p he did receive 25gm 5% albumin for pre-hydration. On day of discharge, BUN/Cr ___. ID: The patient was closely monitored for signs and symptoms of infection and fever. Heme: The patient had blood levels checked daily during their hospital course to monitor for signs of bleeding. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge. If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact ___ regarding these results they will contact ___ before this time. ___ have tolerated a regular diet, passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth. ___ may return home to finish your recovery. Please monitor your bowel function closely. ___ may or may not have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is acceptable; however it is important that ___ have a bowel movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function but ___ should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are expected. However, if ___ notice that ___ are passing bright red blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. If ___ are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that ___ will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the office. If ___ have any of the following symptoms please call the office for advice ___: fever greater than 101.5 increasing abdominal distension increasing abdominal pain nausea/vomiting inability to tolerate food or liquids prolonged loose stool extended constipation inability to urinate Incisions: ___ have a long vertical surgical incisions on your abdomen closed with staples. This is healing well, however, it is important that ___ monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or swelling of the area. ___ may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. The small incisions may be left open to the air. If ___ have steri-strips (small white strips), they will fall off over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or swimming until cleared by the surgical team. Pain: It is expected that ___ will have pain after surgery and this pain will gradually improve over the first week or so ___ are home. ___ will especially have pain when changing positions and with movement. ___ should continue to take 2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around the clock. Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold medication. Do not drink alcohol while or Tylenol. ___ may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every 8 hours for 7 days, please take Advil with food. If these medications are not controlling your pain to a point where ___ can ambulate and perform minor tasks, ___ should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication oxycodone. Please take this only if needed for pain. Do not take with any other sedating medications or alcohol. Do not drive a car if taking narcotic pain medications. Activity ___ may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after surgery. No heavy lifting greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. At your first follow up appointment, your surgical team will clear ___ for heavier exercise and activity as they observe your progress. In the meantime, ___ may climb stairs, and go outside and walk. Please avoid traveling long distances until ___ speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit. Again, please do not drive while taking narcotic pain medications. ___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a new ileostomy placement is dehydration. Stool is no longer passing through the large intestine which is where water is reabsorbed into the body and the stool becomes formed. However, the output from your stoma (intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) will be watery because it is coming from the small intestine which means the water is not reabsorbed by the colon. ___ must measure your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If ___ find that your output has become too much or too little, please call the office. The office nurse or nurse practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice your ileostomy output increasing, drink liquids with electrolytes such as Gatorade. Please monitor for signs and symptoms of dehydration including: dry mouth or tongue, decrease in urination, urine darker in color, dizziness especially when ___ stand, cramps in your abdomen or legs, increased thirst, or weakness. If ___ notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ may eat a regular diet with your new ileostomy. However, it is a good idea to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made to ___ by the ostomy nurses. ___ monitor the appearance of your stoma and care for it as instructed by the ostomy nurses. ___ stoma should be beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times when touched but this will improve over time. The skin around the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the skin around the stoma for any bulging or signs of infection listed above. ___ will be able to make an appointment with the ostomy nurse in the clinic ___ weeks after surgery. Please call the ostomy nurses clinic number which is listed in the ileostomy/colostomy handout packet given to ___ by the nursing staff. ___ will also have a visiting nurse at home for the next few weeks to help to monitor your ostomy until ___ are comfortable caring for it on your own. Follow-up: 1. ___ will need to follow up with both General surgery and Plastic surgery. 2. ___ will need to follow up with your primary care doctor within 1 - 2 weeks, so he can determine which of your home blood pressure medications that ___ should resume. 3. ___ will need an spleen ultra-sound in 3 months to evaluate lesions found on your spleen. Our hope is that ___ will have a quick return to your life and usual activities. Thank ___ for allowing us to participate in your care!

target: Ms ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of severe COPD on home O2 presenting with respiratory distress consistent with COPD exacerbation. #RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient presented with several days of worsening dyspnea on exertion and tachycardia, and subjective fevers of unknown cause, consistent with mild COPD exacerbation. She notably denied cough, sputum production, or upper respiratory symptoms concerning for a typical or more severe COPD flare. Furthermore, since she had been off of an inhaler anticholinergic and oral prednisone for the 2 weeks prior to presentation, her symptoms may simply be the result of severe under-treated COPD. She had already received doses of azithromycin and methylprednisolone in the ED. On arrival to the ICU initially she was comfortable and maintained adequate SPO2 on 4L NC, which is her home oxygen requirement. She was given albuterol/ipratropium nebs Q6h standing, and albuterol nebulizer Q2H PRN dyspnea. She received methylprednisolone 80mg IV q8H x 24 hours, which was then transitioned to prednisone 60mg PO daily which will be tapered slowly with the guidance of her pulmonologist. She was found to be tachycardic on the medical floor so she was changed to xopenex nebs. She should continue her home azithromycin on discharge. #ANXIETY: continued home escitalopram and lorazepam #HYPERTENSION: continued home verapamil and furosemide #OSTEOPOROSIS: continued home vitamin D Transitional issues: - this COPD exacerbation appears to have been provoked by stopping Spiriva, and changing Symbicort to mometasone/formeterol. On discharge from rehab will need to clarify if patient is able to obtain meds at home. - Please taper prednisone by 10mg qweekly

At baseline, she reports that she has mild to moderate dyspnea on exertion (not at rest); she is able to move around her home without much difficulty, although she uses a non-powered wheelchair to get around outside the home. She reports that for the 3 days prior to presentation, she had gradually worsening dyspnea on the exertion that progressed to the point where she was having difficulty moving from her bedroom to the nearby restroom. Over this time, she notes subjective fevers and sweats at night (requiring change of clothes) although she did not take her temperature at home. She tried taking her home nebulizer (Xopenex) and rescue inhaler albuterol more frequently, and increased her oxygen to 5L, but these measures did not help much. She denies cough or sputum production, and has no rhinorrhea or nasal congestion, sore throat, arthralgias/myalgias, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, chest pain, palpitations, or lower extremity edema. She does not 2 pillow orthopnea, but states this is not new. She has no known sick contacts or recent travel. Of note, her COPD medications have recently been changed around. She was previously taking Spiriva (tiotropium) and Advair (fluticasone-salmeterol) and was changed 2 weeks ago to Tudorza Pressair (aclinidium) and Dulera (mometasone-formoterol); however she states her insurance would not cover Tudorza, and so while she has been taking an ___ (Dulera) she has been without an inhaled anticholinergic. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROSURGERY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> headache past ten days <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Image guided right craniotomy for tumor resection <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male who was in good health until 10 days ago, when he began having gradually worsening headaches. These were right-sided and throbbing and initially controlled with over the counter analgesics, but are now refractory to these. He has had no visual changes in association, no N/V or drowsiness. He does not appreciate worsening with cough/strain or sneezing. The patient denies other difficulties, such as weakness, numbness/tingling, visual loss or diplopia, speech abnormalities, gait difficulties, vertigo, dysarthria or dysphagia. He was taken to an outside hospital today, where head CT revealed an intracranial mass lesion. He was given decadron and sent to ___ ER. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> renal cell carcinoma s/p L nephrectomy in ___, no xrt/chemo <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> negative for past malignancies <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS 97.9 60 150/100 12 97% Gen Awake, cooperative, NAD HEENT NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Lungs CTA bilaterally CV RRR, nl S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abd soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted Ext No C/C/E b/l Skin no rashes or lesions noted NEURO EXAM MS ___, alert and oriented x 3. Speech fluent, with normal naming, reading, comprehension and repetition. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. No apraxia. No dysarthria. CN I: not tested CN II: Visual fields were full to confrontation, but with extinction on the left to double simultaneous stimulation. Pupils 4->2 b/l. CN III, IV, VI: EOMI no nystagmus or diplopia CN V: intact to LT throughout; CN VII: slight L NLF flattening and asymmetry CN VIII: hearing intact to FR b/l CN IX, X: palate rises symmetrically CN XI: shrug ___ and symmetric CN XII: tongue midline and agile Motor Normal bulk and tone. No pronator drift D B T WE FE FF IP Q H DF PF TE L ___ ___ Sensory intact to light touch, pinprick, joint position sense, vibration throughout. No extinction to double simultaneous stimulation. Reflexes Br Bi Tri Pat Ach Toes L ___ 2 1 down R ___ 2 1 down Coordination Fine finger movements, rapid alternating movements, finger-to-nose, and heel-to-shin were all normal <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 30PM ___ PTT-26.8 ___ ___ 04: 30PM PLT COUNT-156 ___ 04: 30PM NEUTS-87.7* LYMPHS-10.9* MONOS-1.0* EOS-0.3 BASOS-0.1 ___ 04: 30PM WBC-6.7 RBC-5.41 HGB-15.8 HCT-47.0 MCV-87 MCH-29.2 MCHC-33.7 RDW-13.2 ___ 04: 30PM estGFR-Using this ___ 04: 30PM GLUCOSE-107* UREA N-19 CREAT-1.4* SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-106 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13 MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST ___ 5: 37 AM MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Reason: evaluate lesion Contrast: MAGNEVIST UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old man with intracranial mass lesion REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: evaluate lesion CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None. INDICATION: ___ mid patient, with endocranial mass lesion, to evaluate lesion. PRIOR STUDIES: CT of the head done on ___. TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted imaging of the head was performed without and with IV contrast. FINDINGS: There is a large heterogeneous mass lesion, in the right temporoparietal lobes, with areas of hemorrhage, cystic change, necrosis and large solid enhancing component. The solid competent measures 5.0 x 4.3 cm. There is entrapment of the right temporal horn. There is surrounding significant vasogenic edema, with a leftward shift of subfalcine herniation; measuring approximately 1 cm is unchanged, allowing for technical differences, compared to the prior CT. Mass effect on the right lateral ventricle, is unchanged. There is a 1.7 x 1.6 cm round focus of increased signal on the FLAIR, with enhancement on the post-contrast images in the left parapharyngeal space, which corresponds to an abnormally enlarged lymph node, on correlation with the CT angiogram performed on the same day (series 9, image 1), however, this is not completely included on our present study. IMPRESSION: 1. Large heterogeneous mass lesion in the right parietal and temporal lobes, with cystic, necrotic, hemorrhagic and solid components, the solid competent measuring 5.0 cm, with significant surrounding edema, mass effect and subfalcine herniation, and entrapment of the right temporal horn without significant change since the CT head done the day before. 2. 1.7-cm enhancing focus in the left parapharyngeal region, representing an abnormally enlarged lymph node, representing metastatic involvement. However, this is not completely included on our present study. MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST ___ 2: 41 ___ MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Reason: residual mass? Contrast: MAGNEVIST UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old man with parietal mass s/p resection REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: residual mass? CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None. GADOLINIUM-ENHANCED MR SCAN OF THE BRAIN HISTORY: Status post resection of right parietal mass. Assess for residual tumor. TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted brain imaging was obtained pre- and post-gadolinium administration. COMPARISON STUDY: MR scan of the brain from ___. FINDINGS: There is a lace-like pattern of enhancement along the anteromedial aspect of the right temporal lobe, apparently surrounding the right temporal horn body. There is persistent mild dilatation of the right temporal horn tip, but substantially reduced in extent compared to the prior preoperative study. Additionally, there is presumed hemorrhage along the operative tract, more peripherally situated within the posterior aspect of the right temporal lobe. The extensive edema surrounding the formerly very large tumor appears unaltered in extent. However, overall, there is somewhat less mass effect, though there is still leftward subfalcine herniation present. Numerous tiny areas of elevated T2 signal are seen within the white matter of both cerebral hemispheres, presumably representing chronic small vessel infarctions or post- inflammatory residua. There is soft tissue swelling, subgaleal in locale at the craniotomy site and there is a possible fluid collection or surgical material within the crescent- shaped space between the dura spanning the craniotomy flap and the inner table of the flap itself. There is redemonstration of the well- defined, rounded 21 mm area of contrast enhancement in the left parapharyngeal fat area. Its sharp margination seems most consistent with a benign neoplastic process (question neurogenic tumor). This location would be very unusual for a lymph node or metastatic disease, as was suggested on the previous report. CONCLUSION: Findings suggest that there is residual tumor in the region of the right temporal lobe surrounding the right temporal horn, with mild residual entrapment of this portion of the right lateral ventricle, as described above. Pathology pending at time of discharge <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain or fever. 2. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. Phenytoin Sodium Extended 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day). Disp: *90 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 5. Dexamethasone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO tid (). Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Brain tumor <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR CRANIOTOMY/HEAD INJURY -Have a family member check your incision daily for signs of infection -Take your pain medicine as prescribed -Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, excessive bending -You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have been removed -You may shower before this time with assistance and use of a shower cap -Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation -Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil, Ibuprofen etc. -If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as ordered -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE FOLLOWING: -New onset of tremors or seizures -Any confusion or change in mental status -Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities -Pain or headache that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain medication -Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, tenderness, drainage -Fever greater than or equal to 101° F
target: The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery service with an intraventricular mass in the ICU for close monitoring. He was started on Decadron and dilantin. An MRI was obtained to further characterize the lesion. A staging CT of the torso was obtained which showed metastasis to the lungs, left hilum, and spine. He was hydrated with bicarb fluids and given Mucomyst for renal protection prior to the CT scans. On HD#2 he was transferred to the neuro step down unit. A WAND study was obtained for image guidance of the resection. He was taken to the OR for resection of the brain mass on HD#5. He tolerated the procedure well and initially recovered in the PACU. He was extubated in the PACU without difficulty. He was then transferred to the neurosurgery step down unit. On POD#1 a repeat MRI was obtained which showed no bleeding. He was then transferred to the floor. On POD#2 his diet was advanced, his Foley was removed and he was seen by ___. His Decadron was weaned to 2 mg TID. He was seen by oncology and radiation oncology who recommended follow up in the brain tumor clinic and the ___ clinic. These appointments were set up for the patient. His antibiotics were stopped on POD#4. On POD#5 he was tolerating a regular diet, he had had a bowel movement, he was voiding without difficulty and he was cleared by ___ for home. He was discharged home with follow up instructions.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> These steps can help you recover after your procedure. -Drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. -Avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat fiber-containing foods and avoid foods that can cause constipation. Ask your doctor if you should take a laxative if you do become constipated. -Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual activity in about four to six weeks. Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking prescription pain medications. -You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve -Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor. Should you HOLD ASPIRIN? Unless otherwise advised; If the urine is still pink, hold the aspirin until it has been clear/yellow for at least three days. -If prescribed; complete the full course of antibiotics. -You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange. -Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool softener, NOT a laxative - AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up bleeding. -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised -Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or participate in high intensity physical activity for a minimum of four weeks or until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up -Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains Tylenol -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger). WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER: -Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on routine care and hygiene -Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon. -DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason. -Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only for short-term periods for when leaving the house. -Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)
target: Mr. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ Urology service after bipolar transurethral resection of prostate. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. Mr. ___ received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis and his postoperative course was uncomplicated. He received intravenous antibiotics and continuous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued. His urine was clear-pink and without clots. He remained a-febrile throughout his hospital stay. At discharge, the Mr. ___ had pain well controlled with oral pain medications, was tolerating regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and versed on foley care/hygiene. He was given oral pain medications on discharge and explicit instructions to follow up in clinic for trial of void and to complete his preadmission course of Bactrim.

Pt. voided without issue after removal of foley. Since this time, pt. notes dysuria, specifically tenderness to the urethra region when urinating since the time of removal. He also notes increased urinary urgency. He typically urinates once overnight, however over the last several days has urinated ___ / night. Fevers/chills began on the morning of presentation. Pt. woke up in the afternoon, felt ongoing chills, temperature was noted to be 102.1. Pt. denies any blood in his urine when foley was placed or since removal, noted normal colored urine. ___ RN was contacted and recommended referral to the ED. Pt. otherwise denies lightheadedness, dizziness, CP, SOB, cough, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. In the ED, initial vital signs were: 101.3, 126, 149/84, 16, 98% on RA - Exam was notable for: well healed R groin angio site, no other significant findings - Labs were notable for: WBC 18.3, H/H stable (possibly contracted), INR 1.2, Creatinine 1.3, Bun 23, Mg 1.7, Phos 2.5, INR 1.2, lactate 1.6, UA notable for positive nitrites, positive leuks, >182 WBC, 12 RBC - Imaging: CXR unremarkable - Bladder scan with only 60cc PVR, as such no foley was inserted - The patient was given: 2L NS, Tylenol, and Cipro. During the cipro infusion, pt. had a local skin reaction (phlebitis) with itching and redness that moved into the elbow. Cipro was stopped. Pt. tolerated ceftriaxone 1G IV x1 without difficulty. - BCx/UCx pending - Consults: Neurosurgery was consulted as an FYI given recent procedure. They recommend that if blood cultures are positive to consult ID given that recently surgically implanted hardware cannot be removed. target: ___ yoM with PMH notable for hx of left ICA aneurysm rupture in ___ s/p clipping, residual aneurysm s/p pipeline coiling on ___ complicated by urinary retention, BPH, HTN, HLD, and known Plavix resistance who presented with fevers and dysuria. His urinalysis was grossly positive with leukocytosis consistent with urosepsis. This was thought to be due to foley placement for 7 days due to urinary retention after procedure for aneurysm. He was treated with IV ceftriaxone with improvement in symptoms. He remained afebrile during his hospital course, and leukocytosis downtrended to 10.7 by time of discharge. His urine culture grew gram negative rods. He is to complete 10-day course of cefpodoxime for complicated UTI. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #Recent L ICA Coiling Angio Procedure: Procedure done on ___. Outpatient NSGY working on approving ticagrelor. He was continued on aspirin and ticagrelor as an inpatient #CKD: Pt. with creatinine of 1.3, at baseline. BUN slightly elevated likely pre-renal azotemia in the setting of sepsis ___ urinary source. He received 2L IVF in the ED. His medications were renally dosed. #BPH: Continued home tamsulosin and finasteride #HLD: Continued home fenofibrate #HTN: Continued home amlodipine TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== - New medication: Cefpodoxime 200mg q12h x8 days (last day ___ - Urine culture growing gram negative rods. Inpatient team will follow-up on speciation and sensitivities. - Patient developed skin rash ___ min after receiving IV ciprofloxacin - Please continue to work on insurance approval for ticagrelor - Code status: Full - Contact: ___ (daughter, ___

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with AAA who was admitted to the ___ on ___. The patient was taken to the endovascular suite and underwent FEVAR. For details of the procedure, please see the surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications and was brought to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief stay, the patient was transferred to the ICU at which time the patients lumbar drain was capped, SBPs were controlled briefly on/off nitro and eventually off nitro. On POD#1 we obtained a CTA which was negative for an endoleak, the patient was on a regular diet, drain was capped and we decided that the patient should stay in the ICU overnight. On POD#2, the patients drain came out, we removed the patients foley, A-line and moved the patient to our VICU. On POD#3 the patient was ambulating well and ready for discharge home. Post-operatively, he did well without any groin swelling. He was able to tolerate a regular diet, get out of bed and ambulate without assistance, void without issues, and pain was controlled on oral medications alone. He was deemed ready for discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted for diagnosis and treatment of her shortness of breath. She remained afebrile. Outside records were obtained from ___ and CXR showed evidence of possible pulm edema. # Shortness of breath: DDx was broad, given hx of RA and immunosuppresion. Pleuritic chest pain was thought to be radiation from lung process (given negative extremity exam). CAP was considered most likely etiology of SOB. Less likely etiologies included: legionella (esp considering hyponatremia although urine ag negative)), TB (no hx of exposure, prior PPD negative). She was also treated for pulm edema suggested by CXR (however, echo was not consistent with CHF and EKG not suggestive of MI/ACS as cause of CHF). The patient explains she was in her usual state of health one day prior to admission, and enjoyed a "long" swim on ___. Following her swim she recalls napping for two hours and awakening feeling well. However, she thereafter noted the gradual onset of "discomfort" limited to the "skull" behind her right ear. She describes the discomfort as "dull" and rating ___ on a 10-point pain scale at its worst. She denies radiation of the discomfort. She denies identifiable triggers and exacerbating factors. She denies associated symptoms including phono- and photophobia, nausea, vomiting, neck discomfort, changes in vision, and ear discomfort. She did not treat the HA or mention alleviating factors. She recalls going to bed as usual and falling to sleep without difficulty. She indicates her headache must have "disappeared" in the course of her sleep because she awakened feeling her usual self at a customary time between ___. The pt describes enjoying a "lazy" holiday morning. She recalls preparing breakfast while standing upright between 10: 30 and 11am. At that time, she describes "stretching" by fully extending her neck. In the midst of the maneuver, she states she developed an acute sense of "severe sea-sickness," requiring her to hold on to the nearby oven for support. She says she had diarrhea within about three minutes of the symptom, and had to crawl to the bathroom because attempts to walk resulted in the persistent feeling that she would fall to the right. Other associated symptoms included nausea, although the pt denies vomiting. Following the episode of diarrhea, she assumed a supine position. She says that lying still "with no movement" seemed to decrease the intensity of the feeling of sea-sickness. She denies similar episodes in the past. The sx prompted her to call her PCP, who recommended she go to the ED for evaluation. The pt initially presented to the ___ by ambulance. The pt recalls the persistence of sea-sickness and nausea for about ___ hours until she was given an IV (which she thinks provided NS). This examiner could not elucidate from the available notes what treatment was given. The pt recalls a transient (~30 minute episode) of "blurred vision" while at ___ which she said spontaneously resolved. Notes suggest that the physicians at the OSH noted "faint fatiguing nystagmus to the right" and inferior visual field cuts. Reportedly, the laboratory studies, EKG, and CT performed at the outside hospital were normal or negative. She was subsequently transferred to the ___ for evaluation. En route by ambulance, the pt developed a headache in the occipital regions bilaterally. She recalls a gradual onset of non-radiating discomfort that rated ___ at its worst; she could not define the time from onset to peak discomfort. Since that time, she notes that the headache has moved to the temporal regions bilaterally and is much improved; she rates the discomfort as ___. She attributes the discomfort to "not eating" all day. At the time of evaluation, the pt reports feeling herself. She denies a sense of sea-sickness and nausea. She indicates her vision has completely normalized. Although she continues to experience slight bi-temporal "dull" discomfort, she indicates the sx is unlike her prior migraines. She denies any migraines for the ___ yrs PTA. On neurological review of systems, the pt specifically denies experiencing the "room spinning around" her and the sense that she might lose consciousness. Rather, she volunteers having felt as though she "might fall" from lack of balance. She denies neck pain. Of note, the pt recalls recent redecoration activities and describes herself as a ___. While she does recall assuming a position in which she extended her neck to paint the ceiling, she notes in was a "long time ago." She does note a ~1month hx of second-long episodes of left ___ discomfort. She indicates it feels as though she is "punched in the eye." She recalls 1 episode every ___ days. She denies associated tearing, congestion, and HA; the sx spontaneously resolves. General review of systems is positive for an URI in the 2 weeks prior to admission that included "sinus sx," maximum temperature of ___ F, and sore throat. She denies associated ear discomfort and hearing difficulty. She treated the URI with "homeopathic" remedies and states she was feeling better by one week PTA. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Please discontinue taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your stool (dark, tarry stools) -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised. A narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams from ALL sources -AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. -No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your Urologist -You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or bathe -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery -You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener ___ a gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may be health care spending account reimbursable. -Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative. -Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to further minimize your risk of constipation. -If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.
target: Ms. ___ was admitted to the Urology service after undergoing open radical cystectomy, bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy, partial vaginectomy with ileal conduit. No concerning intrao-perative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. Patient received ___ intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis and deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. Perioperative pain was managed with epidural. On POD2 the patient became extremely agitated overnight requiring IV Haldol. Narcotic was removed from the epidural and toradol was discontinued. Geriatric medicine was consulted who recommended seroquel for agitation and PRN Haldol, which was not needed again. The epidural was removed on POD3 and the patient was started on oral pain medication. No narcotics were needed. The patient was transitioned to lovenox for DVT prophylaxis and started on macrobid for infectious prophylaxis on POD5. With the eventual passage of flatus, diet was gradually advanced. The ostomy nurse saw the patient for ostomy teaching. At the time of discharge the wound was healing well with no evidence of erythema, swelling, or purulent drainage. Her surgical drain was removed. The ostomy was perfused and patent and the ureteral stents were visible. Post-operative follow up appointments were arranged/discussed and the patient was discharged to rehab.

Please follow the provided instructions on administration and disposal of syringes/needles ("sharps"). -Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. Always call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor -___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground. --There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have been applied to reinforce wound closure. Allow these bandage strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may get the steristrips wet. -UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing products and supplements that may have blood-thinning effects (like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.). This will be noted in your medication reconciliation. IF PRESCRIBED (see the MEDICATION RECONCILIATION): -IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You may alternate these medications for pain control. For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief is needed. -Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your stool (dark, tarry stools) -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a couch potato -Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams from ALL sources -AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. -No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your Urologist -You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or bathe -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery -You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener ___ a gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may be health care spending account reimbursable. -Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative. -Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to further minimize your risk of constipation. -If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted given her persistent shortness of breath and hypertension. With regards to her shortness of breath, her work up included a CXR, ECHO, and CTA. Her CXR showed cardiac enlargement and prominent pulmonary vasculature. Her ECHO showed a normal ejection fraction however did have elevated pulmonary artery pressures. This finding prompted a CTA given concern for PE causing pulmonary hypertension. The CTA was negative for PE however did show small pleural effusions. Cardiac enzymes were checked and were normal. Given orthopnea/ PND/ and ?fluid overload on CXR/CTA, lasix was given x2 with excellent UOP response and significant improvement in her symptoms. Throughout her admission she was afebrile and her O2sat remained 95-98% on room air. Following the 2nd dose of lasix she required no further intervention as she was asymptomatic. Ms. ___ blood pressures were very labile and this was the focus of much of the admission. Her blood pressures ranged from 120-170/80-100's. She was started on nifedipine CR 30 daily which was titrated up to 30 BID. Labetalol was initially held on admission as she was started on nifedipine, however this was restarted at 200mg BID ___ persistently elevated BP's and this brought her BP's to normal/ mild range. Ms. ___ was discharged on HD #4 in stable condition. She was no longer short of breath and her blood pressures were stable x 24 hours.

He should follow-up with oncology or his PCP regarding how long to continue on anticoagulation given that inciting cause of DVT was either malignancy or XRT and it is unclear whether the provoking agent can ever be considered removed. . # Acute renal insufficiency: The patient's baseline Cr is 1.2 and was 1.3 on admission. Patient was continued on his home medications of clonazepam (1mg in AM and 0.5 in afternoon) and phenelzine 45mg BID. Ziprazodone was discontinued and 5mg of aripiprazole was started on ___. Aripiprazole was titrated to a dose of 7.5 on discharge and he tolerated it without side effects. Dr. ___ team was contacted and patient recieved ECT on ___, and ___ without reported side effects. He was also given Zofran ODT 4mg bid PRN for nausea, although this did not help. #BPH- continued pt's home meds: tamsulosin 0.4 bid, Avodart 0.5 mg daily Collateral: Spoke with outpatient psychiatrist, Dr. ___. Dr. ___ has been treating patient since ___. Patient frequently makes SI comments that he wants to die because of his intractable nausea. However, patient has never acted on these urges/comments or been psychiatrically hospitalized. Psychiatrist says that he believes patient's nausea is associated with his depression. The nausea has been extensively worked up in past, both by gastroenterology and PCP, and has never revealed any pathology. Dr. ___ that nausea may be a manifestation of psychotic depression, and this is why he referred patient for ECT. Dr. ___ that patient has cluster A traits such as becoming paranoid and he never speaks of friends/family. Dr. ___ that he would prefer Mr. ___ to engage in psychotherapy as well as continuing to see to Dr. ___ psychiatric follow up. Spoke with PCP, ___. PCP relates that patient is relatively new to her. He has previously been extensively worked up in past for nausea ___ years. He had celiac/ h pylori workup that was negative. He has had both colonoscopy and EGD (___ last year) that was nonremarkable, but with a slight hiatial hernia. She has tried zantac/prilosec on him, but these do not seem to help. PCP has also done abdominal MRI, that did not reveal any pathology. She was considering referring him to GI again for furthur workup. PCP agrees that nausea seems linked with depression. PCP also said that in past patient has endorsed suicidal ideation, but he would say he had no intent to kill himself and he never had a plan. Risk Assessment: Patient is at moderate chronic risk of harm to self. Pt has no prior hospitalizations, SAs, family history of SA, no hx of impulsivity or substance use, and is help seeking. However, pt is also an unmarried white, elderly male living alone, has questionable reality testing ability, has frequent SI related to his intolerable and intractable nausea (and has hopelessness and anxiety regarding this), and has the means to act on his plan. It was reassuring to hear from the patient's psychiatrist and PCP, both say that patient's SI is a recurrent problem that is not new, suggesting that patient is at an elevated chronic risk to self, but his imminent risk is low/unchanged. While on Deaconness 4 patient's risk factors were modified by ECT therapy and change to aripiprazole for better cotnrol of both mood and delusions. He was encouraged to participate in outpatient psychotherapy. He reports that if he begins to feel worse he will go to the ___ 1 mile from his house.

target: The patient was admitted for evaluation and management of her facial pain. MRI/MRA/MRV brain was unremarkable, and the etiology of the pain was thought to be a combination of trigeminal neuralgia, temperomandibular joint disease, and migraine. The patient frequently demanded narcotics during her admission, reporting that "nothing works except dilaudid (or IV medications)." She was noted to complain of significantly more discomfort when medical personnel were in the room. There had apparently been some concern for drug-seeking behavior in the past. One-time doses of dilaudid 2mg were given several times when the patient complained of severe pain; she also received morphine and ativan due to pain and anxiety prior to her MRI. She was started on oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) for pain control of trigeminal neuralgia. She was discharged with a prescription for oxcarbazepine as well as dilaudid 2mg PRN (3 tabs total), with instructions to follow-up with pain clinic and dental surgery. The MRI/MRA/MRV was discussed with neuroradiology prior to discharge, but the final read is pending.

target: The patient was admitted to the hospital for elective repair of a ventral hernia. He was taken to the operating room where he underwent a ventral hernia repair with mesh overlay and lysis of adhesion. A thoracic epidural catheter was placed prior to the procedure for pain management. The operative course was stable with minimal blood loss. The patient was extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery room. His post-operative course was stable. The patient resumed a regular diet on the operative day. His foley catheter was removed on POD #1 and the patient voided without difficulty. He was transitioned from intravenous analgesia to an oral pain regimen and his epidural catheter was removed. He was reported to have a white blood cell count of 20 on POD #1. The patient's hemodynamic status remained stable and there were no signs of wound infection. On POD #2, his white blood cell count remained elevated to 22 and he underwent a chest x-ray which revealed a right-sided consolidation. Clindamycin was started for presumed pneumonia. One POD #3 the patient's leukocytosis decreased to 14 and normalized on POD #4. He did have mild blanching erythema surrounding the midline abdominal incision with minimal tenderness and no notable drainage or fluctuance. This remained stable without expansion from POD#2 - POD#4. The patient's vital signs remained stable and he afebrile. He was tolerating a regular diet and resumed his home medication. The patient was discharged home on POD #4 in stable condition. He was given a prescription for a 10-day course of clindamycin. An appointment for follow-up was made with the acute care service and with his primary care provider.

He states that he was up on a lift for work and "lost his momentum" and fell. He reports that he tried to grab a tree "on the way down" and denies any seizure activity. In the ED he was found to have a scalp laceration, L1-l4 transverse process fractures, and L 11th rib fracture. He was admitted to the trauma service, and today an over read of a CT abdomen/pelvis identified non-displaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. One blood culture from HOD #3 return positive for coagulase negative staph, but as all other blood cultures from this admission were negative, and patient was hemodynamically stable, this was most likely a contaminant. Additionally, he was noted to have a patchy erythematous rash on his left lower leg on HOD #3. Thus, he was started on vancomycin empirically for coverage of cellulitis. He continued vancomycin ___ at discharge; at that time, he was transitioned to cephalexin to complete a 7-day course of antibiotics for cellulitis. Although rash appeared atypical for cellulitis, it seemed to improve with antibiotics. ACE wraps were applied to legs, and legs were elevated, as patient reported similar afflication with venous stasis in the past. # Bacteremia: One blood culture from ___ grew coagulase-negative staph. Although this was likely just a contaminant (blood cultures from ___ and ___ without growth, it was covered by empiric antibiotics, as above. target: SUMMARY: ___ with PMH of dilated cardiomyopathy ___ class IV s/p VAD/ICD placement ___ and subsequent OHT ___, newly diagnosed hypothyroidism, presented after routine labs discovered neutropenia. ACTIVE ISSUES # Neutropenia Unclear etiology but a concerning finding. Fortunately, the patient was asymptomatic and had no fevers. Multiple possibilities could be involved: too much immunesuppression from her regimen, an occult infection (no symptoms however), Bactrim toxicity (has been on it for some time though). Had positive urine culture no treatment needed given no symptoms. Hematology and ID were consulted. CMV/EBV viral load negative, flow cytometry negative for concerning clonal populations to suggest hematological malignancy. After stopping Bactrim and decreasing the dose of MMF from 1000mg BID to ___ BID, her ANC slowly recovered and was at 638 at discharge. Therefore, most likely explanation was Bactrim toxicity. Bone marrow biopsy was deferred given recovery. Filgrastim was not given due to no signs of infection. # Dilated Cardiomyopathy s/p OHT Patient endorsed shortness of breath that had been chronic and stable since transplant. She had only mild rejection on recent biopsy and appeared euvolemic. Her immunesuppression was modified to MMF 750mg BID from 1000mg BID. Prednisone was continued at 2.5mg daily. Tacrolimus levels were monitored every day, and due to persistent levels <7, her tacrolimus was increased to 3mg BID from 2mg in AM and 3mg in ___. Bactrim was stopped and atovaquone started at 1500mg daily for PCP and toxoplasmosis prophylaxis. Nystatin was continued. # Hypothyroidism Patient continued to be very symptomatic from her hypothyroidism despite recent increase in levothyroxine. However, TSH appeared to be lowering with increasing free T4. Endocrine recommended continuing current regimen as she had yet to reach steady-state yet. She continued to take levothyroxine 75mcg daily while inpatient. CHRONIC ISSUES # Compression Fractures: She received Tylenol and oxycodone PRN, and continued vitamin D and calcium supplementation. 24hr urine collection for calcium, creatinine, and UPEP were collected based on outpatient endocrine recommendations. # T2DM: Continued home insulin regimen. # GERD: Continued pantoprazole 40mg BID. # Anxiety: Continued sertraline 75mg daily and clonazepam 2.5mg QHS. # Anemia: Chronic but stable. Continued ferrous sulfate 325mg daily. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - Follow up labs on ___ for CBC w/ diff and tacrolimus trough level

target: Pt was admitted to hospital for combined liver/kidney transplant. Pt was brought to OR, after informed consent was obtained, including explaining to the patient the risks associated with the donor liver including steatosis and increased risk of delayed graft function and failure. Intraop significant hemorrhage with no surgical bleeding but a massive amount of just diffuse ooze was encountered. Activated factor VII was given and shortly after the patient began making clot and drying up. It was not thought to be safe to close primarily packed the right upper quadrant and the iliac fossa with sponges and placed a temporary abdominal closure with anticipation of returning the patient to the operating room in 24 hours for washout and definitive closure. Introp received 16 of packed cells, 6 of CRYO, 15 of FFP, 5 of platelets and 1 dose of factor VII. See operative dictation for full details. Transferred to SICU intubated. Overnight, continued transfusions to goal hct >30, plt >100, INR <1.5, receiving 7 units pRBCs, 3 plts. Morning POD#1 returned to OR for Exploratory laparotomy, removal of intra-abdominal packing, liver biopsy, and hepaticojejunostomy. See operative dictation for full details. Transferred back to SICU intubated. ___ U/S showed all vessels are patent. Over next two days hct remained stable ~30 with 4 units pRBCs, 3 units plts. No other transfusions during hospital course. Extubated on ___. Following day had increasing oxygen requirement secondary to pulm edema as mobilized fluid. Was diuresed in SICU and transferred to floor on ___. Course on floor was uneventful, except for pain control. Methadone and dilaudid doses were adjusted apropriately. Was ultimately continued on home methadone dose 35 mg, and pain well controlled with intermittent dilaudid po 5 mg q6 prn. Lateral JP d/c'ed ___, medial removed ___. No evidence ascites leak through JP sites or incision. Immunosuppression was administered and titrated per pathway. Ppx was given per pathway. Pt tolerated regular diet, pain controlled with oral pain medications, voiding without difficulty, and ambulating. ___ felt safe for pt to be d/c'ed home. On day of discharge pt and staff felt it safe for pt to be discharged home with ___.

The patient reports that she was in he USOH until ___ evening; she noticed that her granddaughter "sprayed something," which caused her to start coughing and sneezing. She went in her room to get away from what was irritating her, but continued to cough overnight. On ___, she continued to cough (and the cough become productive of yellow sputum) and began to feel tightness in her chest, so took albuterol nebulizers every four hours. She used her CPAP machine overnight, but couldn't not get comfortable; she turned the setting up from 3 to 5 because she felt short of breath all night. She continued to take her nebulizers this morning, and began to have "shaking chills" this afternoon around 2pm. Her granddaughter called an ambulance, and she was brought to the ED. She reports having some mild nasal congestion for the past few days, as well as a sore throat that developed as a result of her cough. She denies significant headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain or myalgias. She did receive Flu and H1N1 vaccinations this year. Her only sick contacts have been grandchildren, who had "colds." In the ED, initial VS: T 100.5, BP 155/65, HR 97, RR 20, SaO2 100%. A CXR in the ED showed a possible retrocardiac opacity but was otherwise within normal limits. EKG no ischemic changes, biphasic T V4-V5. She was given 125 mg solumedrol, levoflox 750 mg IV, tamiflu, 40 mEq Kcl, 1g tylenol. An influenza DFA was sent, as well as blood cultures. . On arrival to the floor, the patient reported continued shortness of breath and cough. She feels generally "sore" in her chest and abdomen when coughing. She denies chest pain at rest, palpitations or dizziness. . ROS: Denies night sweats, headache, vision changes, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. target: ___ yo F with Asthma, HTN, OSA and GERD who presents with SOB, cough and fever consistent with asthma exacerbation and CAP. . # Asthma exacerbation: Patient known asthma, multiple hospitalization for exacerbations, but no intubations. Most likely cause of exacerbation was felt to be community acquired pneumonia. Influenza was neg by DFA. She was treated with a 7 day course of levofloxacin ending on the day of discharge, and prednisone 60 mg orally for five days, followed by a decrease to 40 mg daily. She was instructed to complete a slow prednisone taper over the next several weeks. Additionally, she was treated with albuterol and atrovent nebulizers every four hours, as well as benzonatate and guafenesin for symptomatic relief. At discharge her cough and shortness of breath were significantly improved, but still decreased from baseline. She was able to ambulate with some mild dyspnea, but no decrease in oxygen saturation. . . # GERD: Pt provided a history of significant reflux symptoms, on PPI at home. Last EGD in ___ was normal. She also provided history of more recent dysphagia particularly with solid foods and pills. She underwent a video swallow evaluation, which showed no evidence of aspiration, but some slight penetration with thin liquids. Consequently, she was advised to take thin liquids slowly (one sip at a time), soft solids and pills whole with puree. Differential for her dysphagia includes esophageal stricture, web, or malignancy. She was proved with an appointment to follow-up in GI clinic three days after discharge for possible EGD to evaluate her dysphagia. She was also continued on omeprazole during this admission. . . # ARF: Creatinine was found to be elevated from baseline several days into admission. This resolved with gentle IV fluids, and was felt to be prerenal in etiology, likely secondary to decreased PO intake during period of dyspnea with asthma exacerbation. . # Hypertension: Continued on home regimen of valasartan and verapamil. . # Anemia: Stable normocytic anemia, which appeared to be at patient's baseline of ___. . # OSA: Uses CPAP at home, which was continued during this admission. . # Hypothyroidism: Continued on home dose levothyroxane.

Echo showed no regional or global systolic dysfunction wtih EF 55% and mild symmetric LV hypertrophy. Pt was started on plavix 75mg daily, asa 325mg daily, simvastatin 40mg daily, metoprolol succ 25mg daily and lisinopril 5mg daily. He will follow up with cardiologist outpatient. . # PUMP: EF 55% with no regional or global systolic dysfunction and mild LV hypertrophy. . # Vaso-Vagal episodes: Likely secondary to manipulation during cardiac cath and post-procedure resulting in increased vagal tone. Pt had 1 episode during the cath procedure and 1 episode while in the CCU. During cath procedure, pt was given atropine and dopamine and had IABP placed. Shortly after cardiac cath, IABP was removed. After all hardwear was removed, pt had no further vagal episodes. . # HTN: Pt takes felodipine at home which was stopped. Started on metoprolol and lisinopril.

target: ___ is a ___ female high school senior with PMH of Prader-Willi, ADHD, chronic migraine without auras, known 2mm R PCA aneurysm, hx Kawasaki's disease who presents with headache, fevers, myalgias, c/f meningitis vs severe migraine in setting of a concominant viral illness, with improving symptoms. # chills # myalgias # headache Initial concern for meningitis given chills, HA, and report of photophobia so started on empiric therapy with vanc/ceftriaxone/acyclovir in the ED after several failed attempts at LP. Her exam on the floor was notable for improving headache, without any evidence of nuchal rigidity, which was not felt to be suggestive of meningitis. Notably, she does have a 2 mm PCA aneurysm; however, given new onset, "worst headache" symptoms and family history of hemorrhagic stroke from aneurysm x2, obtained NCHCT on ___ that was within normal limits. Low suspicion of expanding PCA aneurysm, which would need to be worked up with CTA, because expansion would not be consistent with her systemic symptoms. ___ guided LP performed on ___ with CSF that was bland (1 WBC, 8 RBCs) and antibiotics/antivirals were stopped at that time. Given clear CSF without xanthochromia and only 8 RBCs, as well as negative head CT, subarachnoid hemorrhage felt to be ruled out. Other infectious workup, including CXR, UA, and flu swabs were negative. Some infectious studies, including respiratory viral panel, Lyme, serum anaplasma PCR, CSF HSV PCR, and CSF Arborvirus IgM and IgG, are pending at time of discharge. We think overall picture most consistent with a particularly severe migraine in setting of a concominant viral illness. For patient headache, pain at site of LP attempts, and myalgias, recommended ibuprofen PRN, tylenol, and lidocaine patch. # Migraines Continued home topiramate. # Depression Continued home citalopram. # Allergic rhinitis Continued home loratadine. #Nausea/vomiting Continued home Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO TID:PRN. #Insomnia Continued home HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO/NG QHS insomnia #Menses regulation Held home OCP because non-formulary. =================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== #stopped meds: none #changed meds: none #new meds: none [ ] please follow-up symptoms of chills, myalgias, and headache and ensure resolution [ ] please follow-up studies pending at time of discharge: respiratory viral panel, serum anaplasma PCR, CSF HSV PCR, and CSF Arborvirus IgM and IgG. # CODE: full # CONTACT: ___, Mother, ___

target: #Cervical spondylosis - The patient's symptoms were most attributable to neck muscle strain and spasm on top of her chronic degenerative disc disease. Plain films of the C-spine showed normal bone density, decreased physiologic cervical lordosis, a relatively sharp angle at the level of C5 and C6, a fusion between C6 and C7, mild dorsal spondylosis of the entire C-spine, and minimal arthrosis of the intravertebral joints but no evidence of compression fracture or pathologic vertebral displacement. C-spine MRI preliminarily showed congenital block vertebral body at C6 through T1 with partial obliteration of the dorsal intervertebral disc spaces, multifactorial canal narrowing with no spinal cord deformity or intrinsic signal abnormality at C5-C6, bilateral neural foraminal narrowing with possible bilateral exiting C6 nerve root impingement, and at C4-C5 left endplate/uncovertebral complex encroachment on the left neural foramen with likely impingement upon the exiting left C5 nerve root. MRA of the neck was normal. Pain and spasm was well-controlled on the patient's outpatient medication regimen. The patient was advised not to drive or drink alcohol while taking her usual medications. She was advised to follow up with neurology at her earliest convenience. . #Hyponatremia - Corrected with saline administration. . #Uncomplicated cystitis - Preliminary urine culture grew >100K GNR. Given cipro x 3 days since prior GNR isolates have been sensitive to FQ's. . #Chronic pain - Continued the outpatient regimen. . #Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus - Blood sugars were well-controlled on an insulin sliding scale. . #Epilepsy - No acute issues. Continued tegretol. . #Reflux esophagitis - Continued carafate and PPI. . #Hypertension - Blood pressure well-controlled on imdur. . #Hyperlipidemia - Continued statin.

target: ___ y/o man with PMHx CAD c/b STEMI ___ - posterolateral ventricular branch of the right coronary artery now s/p BMS), Ulcerative Colitis, HTN and HLD presenting with CP in the setting of a known totally occluded RCA at recent ___ cath. # Chest pain/CAD: Given significant cardiac history and concern for unstable angina, patient was initially on a heparin and nitro drip. Home pravastatin was changed transiently to high dose atorvastatin while there was concern for possible ACS/NSTEMI. Metoprolol, aspirin, and IMDUR were continued. Admission EKG was unchanged from prior, serial cardiac enzymes were drawn and remained flat so heparin and nitro were discontinued. On hospital day 1, chest pain recurred while patient was lying in bed. EKG at the time showed TWIs in precordial leads. Patient was restarted on heparin gtt. He was taken for a nuclear stress on ___ that showed no reversible areas of ischemia. He was discharged with nitro SL for symptomatic use and he was also put on amlodipine in case symptoms might be related to coronary vasospasm. Patient's metoprolol was stopped in the setting of SBPs in ___ and starting amlodipine. # ?CHF: most recent ECHO prior to admission showed preserved EF, repeat ECHO done in house showed EF 50-55%. Patient was noted to have slight L>R swelling in ___, LENIs were done which showed no DVT. Patient remained on home lasix and lisinopril and continued to remain euvolemic. # HTN: continued lisinopril, metoprolol, imdur. # HLD: substituted atorvastatin for pravastatin as above # BPH: continued tamsulosin TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # Outpatient team can decide whether pt would benefit from beta blocker, as it was stopped on this admission, in the setting of low systolic blood pressures and starting amlodipine

target: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation of the aforementioned problem. Admission liver/gallbladder ultra-sound revealed multiple small gallstones at the gallbladder neck and mildly thickened gallbladder wall with a normal CBD consistent with acute cholecystitis versus chronic cholelithiasis. He was made NPO, started on IV fluids, and given Morphine IV PRN for pain. He was started on empiric IV Ciprofloxacin and Flagyl. The patient underwent ERCP, which revealed three irregular stones in the distal CBD. A sphincterotomy and stone extraction were successfully performed. He was subsequently placed on aggressive IV fluid hydration and allowed clear liquids. . On ___, the patient then underwent laparoscopic exploration, extensive lysis of adhesions and laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without complication (see Operative Note). The patient was alos found to have chronic cholecystitis intra-operatively. After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, he was returned to the floor tolerating clears, on IV fluids, and received Dilaudid IV PRN for pain control. He remained hemodynamically stable. . Post-operative pain was adequately controlled with the Dilaudid IV PRN, which was converted to oral oxycodone when tolerating clear liquids. Due to inadequate pain control, the oxycodone was changed to Dilauid PO PRN and IV Toradol added with improved pain control. The patient tolerated clears on POD#0. Diet was advanced as to a regular diet by later that day with good tolerability. The patient voided normally. Laparoscopic incisions remained clean and intact. . During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirrometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. Labwork was routinely followed; electrolytes were repleted when indicated. . At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. He was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.
