target: GLOBAL ASSESSMENT: ___ w/ multiple medical problems including chronic pain, narcotic usage, and vascular disease who is s/p a nearly lethal suicide attempt by hanging. He suffered signs/symptoms c/w anoxic brain injury and has resultant cognitive problems. Mr. ___ underwent a fairly lengthy psychiatric admission aimed at reducing his modifiable risk factors for suicide and enhancing his supports and educating his family about his illness and prognosis. During this long hospital course, Mr. ___ progressed in terms of mood and behaviors. After his initial outburst upon arrival to the unit, he had no behavioral problems and complied with treatment in the form of mood stabilizers (Depakote, Klonopin), and antipsychotics (Zyprexa). He also had 1 ECT treatment and underwent a number of neurological and cognitive tests. Mr. ___ in 2 lengthy family meetings and did well in them during which time the team educated patient and family about diagnosis, risk, and treatment plan along w/ discharge planning and outpatient recommendations to best mitigate risk. SAFETY: The pt. was placed on 15 minute checks on admission and remained here on that level of observation throughout. He was unit-restricted. ___: Patient became agitated when informed he could not receive oxycontin and PRN oxycodone at same time; physical altercation with nursing and security where patient swung at security and strangled a nurse. Required 4-point restraints and ___ IM. Team & staff addressed this and patient agreeable with treatment plan. There were no further incidents beyond this point and Mr. ___ had a fairly benign admission with no violence following this initial encounter. He agreed to medication, tolerated it well, and was safe throughout the remainder of his admission. LEGAL: ___ CONSULTS: Pain team Neurology Neuropsychology service ___ opinion by ___ medical director PSYCHIATRIC: #MDD, recurrent, severe w/ psychotic features Patient presented with MSE notable for dysphoric and restricted affect. He endorsed depressed mood although without suicidal ideation on unit, citing his history of impulsive violent behavior toward self and others but paradoxically stating grandchildren as the reason to live yet not being future-oriented toward wanting to live himself. Pt continued on home meds including Trazodone 100 mg PO/NG QHS for sleep with additional 50mg PO QHS PRN insomnia added. ECT discussed as next treatment option, patient provided information for consent and seen by ECT team and medical team for clearance. After altercation with staff after not being able to take oxycodone and oxycontin at the same time, Ativan 1mg PO QID PRN anxiety in place of Clonazepam 1 mg PO QID PRN anxiety. Haldol also increased from 5mg to 10mg PO BID schedule and 5mg PO BID PRN agit/anxiety. Of note, he did endorse recent paranoid thoughts vs. visual hallucinations of a "man in a cowboy hat" in his peripheral vision that he intermittently stated he started noticing several weeks prior to admission, which he stated was not distressful during hospitalization while on haldol. Benztropine 1mg PO TID PRN EPS/stiffness also continued. Divalproex was increased from 500mg PO BID to ___ daily after altercation and for ECT. VPA level 61. Hydroxyzine 50mg PO q4h PRN anxiety was also ordered after altercation. After having one ECT treatment, however, Mr. ___ became very delirious and upset by the treatment. He declined to have any further ECT and the team stopped treatment at his request. Mr. ___ went on to have a "great" mood while in the hospital and did not c/o dysphoria or suicidal thoughts. He responded well to the antipsychotics which were gradually tapered from Haldol over to Zyprexa, as he did experience notable EPS in the form of tremors which were not satisfactorily alleviated w/ Benztropine. Once off the Haldol for about a week, he experienced resolve of EPS and felt much better w/ no residual hallucinations/delusions. Mr. ___ was stable on Depakote, Zyprexa and Klonopin. He tolerated medications and had no side effects. He met w/ the team daily, worked with nursing and sat through lengthy family meetings and participated in a meaningful way. By the end of his admission, he was even attending groups and was an active member. #Cognitive Disorder - Anoxic Brain Injury Prior to ECT, the team performed a MOCA on Mr. ___, on which he scored a ___ on ___. We immediately consulted the neuropsychology team to perform more in-depth memory/cognitive tests. Dr. ___ that Mr. ___ failed the cognitive tests and showed an inability to learn new memories or to recall past ones. Lowest performance on Memory, Delayed Recall, and Language/Repetition. Dr. ___ w/ the team that Mr. ___ results are highly consistent with an anoxic brain injury. A family meeting was held in which we discussed these results w/ patient and his son. In addition, we strongly recommended aftercare referrals to CNU and brain injury clinic that could further assess and treat this condition. GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS: # Anemia ___ RBC: 3.6, Hgb 10.5, Hct: 32.4 checked and uptrending and closer to baseline when compared to previous Hgb 9.8 and Hct 30.1 on ___. Baseline ~ ___. Most likely ___ malabsorption from ulcerative colitis. Patient with adequate dietary intake while on unit. - Consult medicine if downtrending and/or if patient symptomatic - ___ consider nutrition consult # Elevated HCO3 HCO3 35 today ___. Most likely metabolic response/renal compensation for hypoventilation and lower O2 sats (95% today) secondary to level of opiates on board. Team discussed with pt's PCP who stated this is baseline for pt and without contraindication for ECT # Chronic pain - Continued Gabapentin 1200mg PO TID, oxycontin 40 mg PO Q6H and oxycodone 10mg PO Q4H PRN for breakthrough pain. Patient was not to take oxycodone and oxycontin at the same time due to concern for sedation/respiratory depression. -Dr. ___ endorsed concern regarding patient's misuse of opiates and concern that patient may have acquired non-prescribed opiates in the past. He was not in favor of suboxone for Mr. ___ at this time, b/c he had tried in the past with no benefit and in fact, had reportedly abused the medication. The team consulted w/ the pain service at ___ who recommended that we not change his narcotic regimen right now as it would likely lead to escalation in violence. They agreed to f/u with the patient as an outpatient. This plan was shared w/ Dr. ___ pt's PCP who is currently managing pain. He appreciated us getting the pain consult and for keeping him updated about the patient's progress. # HLD - Continued home atorvastatin # UC - Continued home dicyclomine #CAD - Continued home ASA 81 and metoprolol # Rheumatoid arthritis - Continued home Methotrexate 15mg PO weekly and Prednisone 5mg PO QD #Other home medications - Constipation: Colace 100mg PO BID, Senna 8.6mg PO BID PRN - B12 deficiency: cyanocobalamin 50 mcg PO daily - Continued MVIs PSYCHOSOCIAL: #) GROUPS/MILIEU: Mr. ___ was very active in the milieu. He tended to wake up early and sit in the dayroom w/ peers watching tv. Often, the team would find him falling asleep in the dayroom but he was easily redirected. His family visited often and he had good meetings w/ them without any incidents. He also attended OT groups, especially during last week of admission, during which time he was a very active participant and engaged well w/ peers and staff. #) COLLATERAL CONTACTS: - ___ (son, ___: ___ - ___ (ex-girlfriend): ___ - Dr. ___, ___ #) FAMILY INVOLVEMENT: - The family (son and GF) were extremely involved during ___ hospital stay. The team spoke w/ them on the phone, interacted during their regular visits to the unit, and came to 2 formal lengthy meetings w/ the treatment team (each lasting about 1 hour). The family meetings were aimed at educating family and patient about risk, diagnosis and discharge and treatment plan. Family felt patient was doing very well and advocated for d/c. They understood our instruction that pt is high risk for repeat suicide attempt and we reviewed a safety plan in detail. They agreed to call ___ immediately at any worrisome signs of pt's safety. They also understood importance of f/u as we have directed. #) INTERVENTIONS: -ECT - Total of 1 treatment -Medications: Enhanced support w/ psychiatric medications and ongoing general medical medications and analgesics -Consults: Neurology; Pain service; Neuropsyhiatry/Neurocognitive Service -Groups/therapy; provided individual/group and milieu therapy -Aftercare planning; Referrals placed to a variety of sources including; pain service, ___ clinic; brain injury clinic; PCP; Psychiatry and Psychotherapy. -___ Referral: The team submitted a ___ application for the patient to receive services, ex: community-based support. -Family Meetings -Second opinion regarding patient's readiness for d/c and satisfactory mitigation of risk was completed by Dr. ___ ___ director)who supported d/c as there was no further benefit to be gained from a locked inpatient admission. Risk was mitigated to a reasonable degree and pt was d/c home with support of director, interdisciplinary staff (no staff member verbalized opposition of discharge). INFORMED CONSENT: -Haldol, Zyprexa, Depakote, Klonopin Team discussed the indications for, intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of these medications, and risks and benefits of possible alternatives, including not taking the medications, with this patient. We discussed the patient's right to decide whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing any questions about medications with the treatment team, and answered the patient's questions. The patient appeared able to understand and consented to begin the medication. RISK ASSESSMENT: #) Chronic/Static Risk Factors: - Chronic mental illness, co-morbid chronic medical illnesses, hx of suicide attempts (by OD and hanging, all within the past ___ years), age, gender, chronic pain, brain injury. #) Modifiable Risk Factors: - Medication non-compliance: pt tolerated this med regimen well and agreed to c/w meds. His depression was adequately treated and he felt well at time of d/c. - lack of connection to outpatient mental health treaters: aftercare planning - many referrals were made including to psychiatric care and a psychiatric partial hospital and ___ services, among multiple other things - Opioid dependence: pain consult was appreciated during admission and they will f/u in clinic w/ patient. Appt was made for f/u with pain service and also Dr. ___ - ___ brain injury - pt was referred to ongoing services within ___ and brain injury center. (he indicated he might have trouble attending appointments due to distance from home and the team offered to arrange a PT1 - pt and son refused stating that they would make something work within the family. All were advised that pt should not drive until cleared by PCP and verbalized understanding) - loss of long term relationship (end of a decades long relationship): ___ was involved in pt's care and was supportive - aftercare - we recommended a ___ and pt agreed - ___ ___ agreed to f/u with patient upon d/c for daily assessments regarding medication management and safety. #) Protective Factors: - Somewhat help-seeking and future oriented for serving as father figure for son and grandchildren - Lack of suicidal thoughts/intent/plan at time of d/c and during weeks preceding d/c along w/ participation in d/c planning, f/u care and future orientation - ___ faith PROGNOSIS: Poor - ___ is a ___ male with a history of severe major depressive disorder, with at least 3 previous suicide attempts, also with chronic back and leg pain, CAD s/p 5-vessel bypass and 2 stents, ulcerative colitis. He has now suffered an anoxic brain injury following last hanging attempt, and he is very impulsive. If patient f/u as directed, he will be able to improve his prognosis over time.

target: SUMMARY STATEMENT ================= Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a history of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties, DM, and secondary adrenal insufficiency, presenting with polymicrobial R heel infection s/p debridement x2, with wound vac and on IV vanc/cefepime/flagyl for 6 week course per ID recommendation. ACUTE ISSUES ADDRESSED: ===================== #Polymicrobial R heel osteomyelitis, R heel ulcer infection History of T2DM and severe PVD s/p R bypass with multiple angioplasties, chronic right heel ulcer, presented with heel ulcer drainage, pain and erythema. She underwent OR I&D/debridement x2 (___) with Podiatry. Operative debridement yielded deep purulence down to the calcaneus. Due to the chronicity of the ulcer and the proximity of the purulence so close to calcaneus, decision made to treat for osteomyelitis. Vascular surgery was consulted and said there was no need for intervention. Wound cultures grew two morphologies of e. coli (which had no clear PO options for treatment based on sensitivities, but were susceptible to CTX), b frag, and coag neg staph sensitive to clinda/vanc. No pseudomonas. Blood cx no growth. Infectious Disease team was consulted and recommended cefepime, vancomycin, and metronidazole given possibility of pseudonomonas ___ diabetic patient, even if not grown on culture. Antibiotic course planned for 6 weeks from last instrumentation ___, therefore finishing ___. She was cleared by Physical Therapy for home. She will follow-up with podiatry, vascular, and ID. Her daughter ___ was trained on taking care of the wound vac at home (per Podiatry, anticipate several weeks) and home antibiotic administration. She will have weekly labs checked. #Revision of diagnosis: No secondary adrenal insufficiency During last hospitalization, as part of workup for hyponatremia, she was thought to have secondary adrenal insufficiency. The etiology was not elucidated, however, she was started on hydrocortisone 10 mg QAM. Given active infection and surgery this admission, she received stress dose steroids with a taper. Following this, the ID team noted a positive quantiferon gold that had resulted from the last admission. Endocrine was reconsulted to further investigate the AI diagnosis as patient might require latent TB treatment if planning for chronic steroids. On repeat ___ stim testing, pt had appropriate and robust response, making adrenal insufficiency unlikely. MRI adrenal protocol was within normal limits. ACTH levels were normal. This admission, adrenal insufficiency workup was again pursued and it was determined patient does not have this. Steroids were discontinued, pressures were maintained, and there was no ill effect. Several days later, patient's sodium downtrended. Urine studies consistent with SIADH so patient placed on fluid restriction of 1.5 liters. Her sodium levels fluctuated but ultimately stable and near normal limits. #Diabetes Mellitus, type 2 On admission, held home metformin 500mg PO BID, continued home lantus 10 units QHS, and provided insulin sliding scale. Elevated blood sugars ___ the setting of stress-dose steroids, were covered with NPH, subsequently discontinued. On ___, metformin 500mg BID was restarted as patient awaiting placement. #Hypertension Patient's blood pressures were elevated and lisinopril was uptitrated from 10mg to 40mg with good results. # Anemia Underlying Iron deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. Hgb 9.1 on admission. Received 2U pRBC following surgeries. Patient was given IV ferrous gluconate for 4 days. Stable rest of admission. No pulmonary sx, CXR unconcerning, and adrenals within normal limits on CT. Pt is at moderate risk for reactivation given insulin-dependent diabetes, though does not have adrenal insufficiency and so will not receive further steroids. ___ consultation with ID, treatment of latent TB was deferred. # Peripheral vascular disease History of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties. target: Patient was admitted to the transplant surgery service with the bacteremia and sepsis. He was admitted to the ICU. Neuro: Since the time of admission patient was arousable and responded to commands. He remained at his baseline until the day he decompensated when his metal status has worsened and upon intubation, required no sedation. He received minimal pain medications for abdominal pain/discomfort. CV: The patient was initially stable from a cardiovascular standpoint. He required vasopressors upon admission, in the next ___ hours he was weaned of the pressors. He developed vasopressor requirement and became hemodynamically unstable approximately 48 hour prior to his demise. Following the aspiration event on the floor level of care on ___, patient was transferred to ICU, where he drooped his systolic blood pressure shortly after. He was on one vasopressor for the 24 hours, later on 2 pressors, yet his sbp was in ___. The family made a decision to withdraw life support including vasopressors on ___ in the early mid-afternoon. Patient expired several hours after. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint initially. On ___ he vomited and aspirated. His oxygen saturation dropped and he was transferred to the ICU. His oxygen saturation was low, his mental status worsened, thus he was intubated. He remained intubated until he expired. GI/GU/FEN: Patient was found to have C. difficile colitis. He was fed via TPN. The electrolytes was initially repleated. The hyperkalemia was treated with kayaxylate. Patient also underwent CVVH. The CVVH no longer continued after ___, when patient was intubated, due to family wishes. Patient had diagnostis paracenthesis, which did not show SBP. ID: He was treated for C. difficile colitis initially with PO vancomycin and IV flagyl as well as tigacycine. The Klebsiella bacteremia was treated with meropenem. Prior to the cultures becoming available, patient also recieved amikacin and cefepime. He was afebrile for most of the hospital stay. Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly. Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. As patient status declined rapidly on ___ following the aspiration event, family made a well thought out decision to minimize the patient's suffering as his prognosis was not favorable. Patient was initially made DNR status for about 24 hours. Next, the family made the patient CMO with continued ventilation on ___. Patient expired one to hours after all the vasopressors were stopped. He was started on morphine gtt. He expired comfortable, with no agonal breaths observed. The medical examiner as well as the family refused an autopsy.

You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by your physician. 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue Lovenox for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Aquacel dressing in place until your follow up with Dr. ___ ___ in ___. It is okay to shower but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound after aqaucel is removed each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Sutures will be removed by your doctor at follow-up appointment. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, and wound checks. 11. ACTIVITY: Touch down weight bearing on the operative extremity. Two crutches or walker at all times. Mobilize. No ROM. Knee immobilizer at all times (can come out daily for skin checks). No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. 12. PICC CARE: Per protocol 13. target: The patient presented from ___ to ___ ___ where he was admitted to the Orthopaedic service. He was a direct admit for infected left total knee replacement. On physical exam of the left knee, his surgical staples were intact, with mild serosanguineous drainage from the inferior portion of the wound. There was local erythema and edema of the lower extremity. ID was consulted and made recommendations including for his antibiotic regimen (please see their note for full details). Per their recommendation, a PICC was placed and his right femoral catheter was removed on ___. The patient was transferred to the Joints service on the ___ on ___. The patient was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: On POD #0, patient was given 5mg of Coumadin for INR 1.3. On POD #1, patient had a hematocrit of 22.7 and low magnesium level of 1.5, which was repleted. INR was 1.9 and Coumadin was held. Patient was triggered for asymptomatic hypotension and 1 liter bolus of IV fluids was given. In the afternoon, patient was noted to be drowsy per RN and a repeat hematocrit was obtained, which was stable at 22.9. On POD #2, hematocrit was 22.8 and blood pressures were within normal limits. Patient was not given a blood transfusion given that he was asymptomatic with stable vital signs. INR was 2.5 and coumadin was held. Patient's hemovac drain remained in placed due to high output. On POD #3, his hematocrit remained stable at 23.1 and his vital signs remained stable. He was started on 40mg of lovenox daily after his INR returned at 1.7. His pain medication was then switched to Dilaudid for inadequate pain control. The drain remained in place. On POD #4, the patient's pain was better controlled with Dilaudid and expressed feeling better. His hematocrit returned at 22.2 and his vital signs continued to remain stable. On POD#5, the drain was removed, his hematocrit was 23.1 with asymptomatic mild hypotension, systolic blood pressure of 98, he was given a bolus, 500cc of normal saline. At the time of discharge his blood pressure was 120 systolic and the patient was asymptomatic. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis on POD #0 and Coumadin was dosed daily based on INR levels. He was then switched to Lovenox 40mg daily on POD#3. The ___ surgical dressing will remain in place until follow visit with Dr. ___ on ___. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a diabetic diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact. The patient's weight-bearing status is toe touch weight bearing on the operative extremity. No range of motion of left knee. Please keep the knee immobilizer on for ambulation. Please use walker or 2 crutches at all times. Mr. ___ is discharged to rehab in stable condition.

You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression.
